message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest a congenital heart disease, specifically ventricular septal defect (VSD) with associated pulmonary congestion and left-to-right shunting across the VSD. Digital clubbing is a potential long-term complication of chronic hypoxemia associated with congenital heart disease. Thrombocytosis and secondary hypertension are not associated with VSD. Aortic dissection typically occurs in older patients and is not associated with VSD.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and cardiac auscultation suggest a congenital heart disease, likely Ventricular Septal Defect (VSD). VSD can lead to pulmonary hypertension, which in turn can cause digital clubbing. Thrombocytosis, secondary hypertension, and aortic dissection are not common complications of VSD.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, including crackles in both lower lung fields and a murmur over the left lower sternal border, suggest congestive heart failure or congenital heart disease. Digital clubbing is a common feature of congenital heart disease and is caused by chronic hypoxia. Thrombocytosis, secondary hypertension, and aortic dissection are not commonly associated with these symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has symptoms of a congenital heart defect, specifically a ventricular septal defect (VSD) as suggested by the holosystolic murmur and diastolic rumble. If left untreated, VSD can lead to Eisenmenger syndrome, which can cause digital clubbing due to chronic hypoxemia. Thrombocytosis, secondary hypertension, and aortic dissection are not typically associated with VSD.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical examination suggest that the patient has a congenital heart defect, possibly a ventricular septal defect (VSD). If left untreated, VSD can cause pulmonary hypertension which can lead to digital clubbing. Thrombocytosis, secondary hypertension, and aortic dissection are not typical complications of VSD.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical examination findings suggest that the patient has a congenital heart defect, specifically ventricular septal defect (VSD), which is causing the holosystolic murmur and diastolic rumble. If left untreated, the patient is most likely to develop digital clubbing, which is a sign of chronic hypoxemia. Thrombocytosis and aortic dissection are not associated with VSD. While secondary hypertension can be associated with some congenital heart defects, it is not the most likely consequence of VSD.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of a holosystolic murmur over the left lower sternal border and a diastolic rumble heard best at the apex, along with the history of recurrent respiratory infections, suggests the patient has ventricular septal defect (VSD). If left untreated, VSD can lead to increased pulmonary vascular resistance and eventually, digital clubbing. Thrombocytosis, secondary hypertension, and aortic dissection are not typically associated with VSD.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has symptoms of a congenital heart disease, specifically ventricular septal defect (VSD) as indicated by the holosystolic murmur and diastolic rumble. If left untreated, VSD can lead to increased blood flow in the lungs, which can cause clubbing of the digits due to oxygen deprivation. Thrombocytosis, secondary hypertension, and aortic dissection are not commonly associated with VSD.

We refer to medical textbooks and resources for help. The symptoms described in the patient suggest ventricular septal defect (VSD), which can cause increased blood flow to the lungs leading to pulmonary hypertension and eventually right-to-left shunting of blood. This can result in clubbing of fingers and toes due to chronic hypoxemia. Thrombocytosis, secondary hypertension, and aortic dissection are not commonly associated with VSD.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest Congenital heart disease, and among the options, digital clubbing is a characteristic of cyanotic heart disease, which is associated with congenital heart disease. Thrombocytosis and secondary hypertension are not associated with congenital heart disease. Aortic dissection is more likely to occur in older patients with hypertension or connective tissue disease.
